author: By Alex Marshall
title: A Theater Serves as a Courthouse, Provoking Drama Offstage
description: Black artists and activists in Birmingham, England, say the city’s largest playhouse has sold out by leasing its auditoriums to the criminal justice system.
content: BIRMINGHAM, England — One recent Monday, Sarah Buckingham walked into an auditorium at Birmingham Repertory Theater, strode up some steps to a platform and looked out at her audience. She was in full costume, with a wig, and everyone rose to their feet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise
title: Why Rage Over the 2020 Election Could Last Well Past Trump
description: A vast majority of Americans do not approve of the riot at the Capitol. But experts warn that the widespread belief there was election fraud, while false, could have dangerous, lasting effects.
content: WASHINGTON — For many Trump supporters, the inauguration of Joseph R. Biden Jr. this week will be a signal that it is time to move on. The president had four years, but Mr. Biden won, and that is that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Yellen Readies Big Changes for Treasury
description: From financial regulation to minority lending, Biden’s pick is poised to change course sharply from the policies of Secretary Steven Mnuchin.
content: WASHINGTON — Janet L. Yellen, President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s nominee for Treasury Secretary, will tell lawmakers at her confirmation hearing on Tuesday that the United States needs a robust set of fiscal stimulus measures to get the pandemic-stricken economy back on track and that now is not the time to worry about the nation’s mounting debt burden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff
title: Once a Trump-Basher, Mexico’s Leader Misses Him Already
description: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador came to appreciate Mr. Trump’s hands-off style, and is already making waves with an incoming administration he expects to be more meddlesome.
content: MEXICO CITY — President Trump called Mexican migrants rapists, threatened his neighbor with a trade war, kicked tens of thousands of asylum seekers out of the country, built up the border wall and promised to make Mexico pay for it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: It’s Not Your Parents’ Hip Replacement Surgery
description: Perhaps the most exciting aspect of modern hip replacement is the increasing use of robotic surgery.
content: If I’ve learned anything during nearly six decades of reporting on medical science, it’s that the longer you wait, the better the methods of prevention, diagnosis and treatment are likely to become. That’s true for almost every field of medicine — cardiology, gastroenterology, oncology, etc. And it may be particularly relevant for orthopedic surgery, a specialty facing ever-increasing demands from an aging population with bones, joints, ligaments, tendons and muscles that break down after decades of wear and tear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: When the Removal of 2 N.F.L. Stars From Playoff Games Is Progress
description: Lamar Jackson and Patrick Mahomes did not return to games over the weekend after exhibiting concussion symptoms, satisfying critics who have long accused the league of turning a blind eye to brain injuries.
content: In a season dominated by the N.F.L.’s efforts to play a full schedule during a pandemic, many other health issues have been overshadowed, particularly concussions, an issue that has dogged the league in years past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lucy Tompkins and Carl Zimmer
title: As the U.S. surpasses 24 million cases, Los Angeles confronts a more contagious variant.
description: At least two new variants of the virus — one discovered in Britain and another first detected in Denmark — are now showing up in California.
content: As the total number of U.S. coronavirus cases surpassed 24 million on Monday, Los Angeles County, one of the hardest-hit areas, may face even more dire weeks ahead. Deaths in the county have continued to climb as the national death toll nears 400,000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: How Theater Stepped Up to Meet the Trump Era
description: As artists saw liberties threatened and inequities exacerbated, the stage became more thrillingly urgent than it had been in decades.
content: On the Tuesday morning in June 2015 when Donald J. Trump waved his way down, down, down a golden-edged escalator in Trump Tower to announce his presidential candidacy on a stage below, he set the United States on a trajectory that much of the country wasn’t anticipating. The theater, for one, was busy heading in a very different direction, and in a vastly different spirit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Biden Will Be the Oldest President to Take the Oath
description: Until Joe Biden is sworn in on Wednesday, President Trump holds the record for the country’s oldest chief executive. At 42, Theodore Roosevelt was the youngest.
content: When Joseph R. Biden Jr. takes the oath of office on Wednesday, he will be the oldest person ever sworn in as president. Mr. Biden turned 78 in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: ‘Expedited Spree of Executions’ Faced Little Supreme Court Scrutiny
description: In its last six months, the Trump administration put more than three times as many prisoners to death as the federal government had in the previous six decades.
content: In 2015, a few months before he died, Justice Antonin Scalia said he would not be surprised if the Supreme Court did away with the death penalty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: She Thought the Grizzlies Wanted Hiring Advice. They Wanted Her.
description: Sonia Raman had spent years studying N.B.A. games as she coached Division III women’s basketball at M.I.T. Then the Memphis Grizzlies called about an opening for an assistant coach.
content: The women’s basketball team at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology knew something was up when Sonia Raman, the coach with the most wins in the program’s history, organized a video meeting on short notice in September. Most of the players figured it had to do with the coming season, and with complications stemming from the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Audra D. S. Burch, John Eligon and Michael Wines
title: The Words of Martin Luther King Jr. Reverberate in a Tumultuous Time
description: Dr. King’s speeches have particular resonance today amid a year of sickness and death, Black Lives Matter protests and the storming of the Capitol.
content: He lived and died in a time of tumult and a racial awakening, so perhaps it is no surprise that the 35th national celebration of the life and legacy of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on Monday has particular resonance amid one of the most traumatic seasons in memory: A raging pandemic. Protest and civil unrest after the killing of Black people by the police. A momentous election. And an insurrection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Incest Scandal Sets Off a New #MeToo Movement in France
description: A wave of testimonies from people who say they were victims of incest has surfaced on Twitter after a scandal in which a prominent French intellectual was accused of abusing his teenage stepson.
content: PARIS — The testimonies have surfaced by the hundreds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Who Was the First New President to …?
description: The inauguration has evolved a bit from George Washington’s day.
content: The basics of the inauguration are simple: The new president takes a 35-word oath on a date prescribed by the Constitution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meri-Jo Borzilleri
title: With Another Olympic Chance in View, Nathan Chen Dominates on the Ice
description: Chen, 21, claimed his fifth straight U.S. figure skating championship on Sunday, continuing a winning streak that started after a disappointing result at the 2018 Winter Games.
content: The transformative moment of Nathan Chen’s figure-skating career came barely 24 hours after its greatest disappointment.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Fear of Sudden Death Governs Capital as Attacks Pick Off Afghans
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, January 18, 2021.
content: “It’s about an atmosphere of fear. If it continues, you won’t have the space needed for a democracy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dylan Loeb McClain
title: Martinus Veltman, Who Made Key Contribution in Physics, Dies at 89
description: He shared a Nobel Prize for research that helped explain the fundamental forces in the universe.
content: Martinus J.G. Veltman, a Dutch theoretical physicist who was awarded the Nobel Prize for work that explained the structure of some of the fundamental forces in the universe, helping to lay the groundwork for the development of the Standard Model, the backbone of quantum physics, died on Jan. 4 in Bilthoven, the Netherlands. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Wu
title: Twins With Covid Help Scientists Untangle the Disease’s Genetic Roots
description: “I want to know,” one twin said, “why did she have Covid worse than me?”
content: After 35 years of sharing everything from a love for jazz music to tubes of lip gloss, twins Kimberly and Kelly Standard assumed that when they became sick with Covid-19 their experiences would be as identical as their DNA.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina
title: Alex Padilla, California’s First Latino Senator, on Needing to ‘Walk and Chew Gum’ in Washington
description: He was appointed to fill Kamala Harris’s seat, and will take office as his state struggles with record Covid rates, especially in the neighborhood he grew up in.
content: LOS ANGELES — As Kamala Harris steps into her role as vice president and out of her Senate office this week, the Democrat Alex Padilla will become the first Latino senator from California, a state where Latino residents make up 40 percent of the population, and will be one of six in the Senate. Mr. Padilla, who has been California’s secretary of state since 2015, is heading to Washington at a time when the country — and California — is deeply mired in the pandemic and a sluggish vaccine rollout. His own political career began with immigration activism, and he believes that the country needs a pathway to citizenship for all undocumented immigrants. He said he was confident that the Senate would be able to focus on an impeachment trial and the pressing need to get the pandemic under control — “we will walk and chew gum at the same time.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Can the World Break Up With Fossil Fuels? Watch the Conversation.
description: The Times is hosting a series of virtual events ahead of global climate talks in November. This month’s topic: the demand for energy and what can be learned from the pandemic.
content: The coronavirus pandemic collapsed demand for energy, with oil prices plunging into negative territory briefly in late April. But as the world looks toward recovery, will this break the global addiction to fossil fuels, or will the “new normal” end up looking much like the old one? How can we accelerate the rise in renewable energy sources to meet urgent global demand throughout the recovery? How will businesses with global operations adapt to support this transformation? And could a green recovery provide the necessary boost to strengthen commitment to climate goals the world so badly needs?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: He Crusaded Against Gun Violence in Baltimore. Then He Was Shot and Killed.
description: Dante Barksdale helped lead Baltimore’s Safe Streets program and was a nephew of Nathan Barksdale, a drug trafficker known as Bodie who was an inspiration for the character Avon Barksdale in “The Wire.”
content: A leader of a city campaign to quell gun violence in Baltimore who was widely recognized for canvassing streets prone to gang wars with words of reconciliation was shot and killed on Sunday, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Matthew Lewis Can’t Believe He’s a Romantic Lead, Either
description: The actor, best known as the clumsy Neville Longbottom of “Harry Potter” fame, is a dashing suitor in the PBS reboot of “All Creatures Great and Small.”
content: Matthew Lewis’s face is everywhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Bruenig
title: The Fire Last Time
description: Timothy McVeigh’s 1995 attack in Oklahoma City spurred legislation that gutted death row inmates’ rights. In the wake of the siege of the Capitol, will we make a similar mistake?
content: Robert Pruett was 17 when he was sentenced to 99 years in prison for being party to his father’s fatal stabbing of a neighbor in 1995. Five years later, Mr. Pruett was sent to death row after being convicted of stabbing a guard to death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: Biden’s Covid-19 Plan Is Maddeningly Obvious
description: It is infuriating that the Trump administration left so many of these things undone.
content: I wish I could tell you that the incoming Biden administration had a genius plan for combating Covid-19, thick with ideas no one else had thought of and strategies no one else had tried. But it doesn’t.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: He Climbed 800 Feet in a Wheelchair. Hong Kong Watched in Awe.
description: Lai Chi-wai didn’t reach his goal of ascending a skyscraper by rope. It hardly made his feat any less impressive.
content: HONG KONG — Racked by cold and dizzy with vertigo, Lai Chi-wai struck his helmet again and again to stay alert.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Selam Gebrekidan and Matt Apuzzo
title: Covid Response Was a Global Series of Failures, W.H.O.-Established Panel Says
description: An interim report is both a bleak recounting of deadly missteps and an early blueprint for repairs: “We have failed in our collective capacity.”
content: Laying bare a yearlong cascade of failures, a World Health Organization panel recounts in a damning report how governments and public health organizations worldwide responded slowly and ineffectively to the coronavirus, despite years of warnings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: China’s College Graduates Can’t Find Jobs. The Solution: Grad School.
description: The government is expanding university capacity, but some young people worry that the option will only postpone a crisis stemming from a shortage of well-paying work.
content: Graduation was fast approaching, but Yang Xiaomin, a 21-year-old college student in northeastern China, skipped her university’s job fair. Nor did she look for positions on her own. She didn’t think she had a chance of landing one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: After Capitols Become Fortresses, Far-Right Protesters Are Mostly a No-Show
description: A mass deployment of troops and police across the country turned statehouses into citadels. But, for the most part, far-right groups stayed away from protests on Sunday.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — And this is how the last weekend of the Trump presidency wound down, with state capitols across the nation ringed by barricades, military vehicles guarding closed-off streets and Washington, D.C., all but shut down. In the end, it was for a handful of protesters, most from the right, a few from the left, many looking more like ragtag stragglers than the furious mob of Trump supporters that ransacked the U.S. Capitol more than a week ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roy Furchgott
title: The Races Are Digital, and So Are the Ads, but the Money Is Real
description: When the pandemic shut down motorsports, sim racing filled the gap. Can it hold on to fans and sponsors when sports get back to normal?
content: It takes more than gasoline to make a racecar run.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mona El-Naggar and Yousur Al-Hlou
title: Egypt Denied an Oxygen Failure Killed Covid Patients. We Found That It Did.
description: For many Egyptians, a video offered a rare and uncensored view of the coronavirus’s real toll at the peak of Egypt’s second wave of the pandemic.
content: EL HUSSEINEYA, Egypt — A cry pierced the night from the balcony of an Egyptian hospital. A nurse was screaming that the patients in the Covid intensive care unit were gasping for air.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño, Manuela Andreoni and Letícia Casado
title: Brazil Starts Vaccinations Amid Rise in Covid Cases and New Variants
description: The country has relatively few doses and is paying a price for its leader’s slow pursuit of vaccines early on. That lapse may hinder Brazil’s ability to fight worrisome variants.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil on Monday kicked off its nationwide coronavirus vaccination campaign, providing a glimmer of hope in a nation where political infighting, a strained health care system and lax precautions have given the virus free rein.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt, Jennifer Steinhauer and Helene Cooper
title: Pentagon Accelerates Efforts to Root Out Far-Right Extremism in the Ranks
description: The nation’s military has a history of downplaying white nationalism and right-wing activism, but the siege of the Capitol has created a new urgency for dealing with them.
content: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon is intensifying efforts to identify and combat white supremacy and other far-right extremism in its ranks as federal investigators seek to determine how many military personnel and veterans joined the violent assault on the Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: Pelosi increases pressure on Pentagon, saying Trump loyalist isn’t qualified to be the N.S.A.’s top lawyer.
description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi wrote a letter to the acting secretary of defense demanding that he not install a Trump loyalist as the top lawyer at the National Security Agency, her office announced Monday.
content: Speaker Nancy Pelosi wrote a letter to the acting secretary of defense demanding that he not install a Trump loyalist as the top lawyer at the National Security Agency, her office announced Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Deborah Rhode, Who Transformed the Field of Legal Ethics, Dies at 68
description: A Stanford professor, she pushed the legal profession to confront the ways it failed clients and to be more inclusive of women.
content: Deborah L. Rhode, a law professor who transformed the field of legal ethics from little more than a crib sheet for passing the bar exam into an empirically rich, morally rigorous investigation into how lawyers should serve the public, died on Jan. 8 at her home in Stanford, Calif. She was 68.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Giuliani will not be part of Trump’s defense in the Senate impeachment trial.
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the president’s attorney, said he was taking part in the trial and then a day later said he would have no involvement.
content: President Trump’s personal lawyer, Rudolph W. Giuliani, will not be taking part in the president’s defense in the Senate trial for his second impeachment, a person close to Mr. Trump said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Black Music Has a New Home in Nashville
description: The National Museum of African American Music is opening in the capital of country music. And that’s exactly where it belongs.
content: NASHVILLE — The long awaited ribbon cutting for the National Museum of African American Music is Monday, Martin Luther King’s Birthday, in the heart of the tourist district here. But there’s still so much construction equipment enveloping 5th + Broad — Nashville’s sprawling new mixed-use development at the corner of Fifth Avenue North and Broadway — that the museum can be easy to miss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman, Katie Benner and Alan Feuer
title: Investigators Eye Right-Wing Militias at Capitol Riot
description: The F.B.I. has arrested several members associated with violent right-wing extremist groups known as the Oath Keepers and the Three Percenters.
content: WASHINGTON — F.B.I. agents and prosecutors investigating the Jan. 6 riot at the Capitol have increasingly shifted their attention to dangerous right-wing extremist groups, arresting several people in recent days suspected of taking part in the violence and of possessing ties to notorious militias such as the Oath Keepers and the Three Percenters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Morgan Wallen Debuts at No. 1 and Smashes a Country Streaming Record
description: “Dangerous: The Double Album” had 240 million streams — more than double the previous high set by Luke Combs.
content: The new year has started with a bang for the music industry, as two young stars have arrived with monster streaming hits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Suhasini Raj
title: Amazon Web Drama Draws the Wrath of India’s Hindu Nationalists
description: Artists say officials tied to the country’s ruling party use pressure to stem criticism. Streaming services hoping to tap the Indian market’s potential have been caught in the middle.
content: NEW DELHI — Bollywood once again has fallen into the cross hairs of India’s Hindu nationalist ruling party — and major Western streaming services like Amazon and Netflix increasingly find themselves caught in the middle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Drew Brees Considering Retirement After Playoff Ouster
description: Brees, 42, said he will weigh ending his 20-year career after the Saints’ loss to Tom Brady’s Buccaneers in the divisional round.
content: Drew Brees, who overcame a career-threatening shoulder injury to become the most statistically prolific quarterback in N.F.L. history, likely played the final game of his 20-year career Sunday, when his Saints lost, 30-20, to the Tampa Bay Buccaneers in a divisional round playoff game in New Orleans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: In farewell video, Melania Trump, who like her husband bristled at White House norms, defends her legacy.
description: Melania Trump defended her legacy as first lady in a video posted on Monday, asked Americans to “lead by example” in caring for others, and name-checked her Be Best platform, which over the years never grew into a comprehensible policy effort.
content: Melania Trump defended her legacy as first lady in a video posted on Monday, asked Americans to “lead by example” in caring for others, and name-checked her Be Best platform, which over the years never grew into a comprehensible policy effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden is expected to cancel the Keystone XL Pipeline permit on his first day in office.
description: Environmentalists have long targeted the nearly 1,200-mile pipeline as both a contributor to climate change and a symbol of the country’s unwillingness to move away from an oil-based economy.
content: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. is expected to cancel the Keystone XL pipeline permit on his first day in office, quickly reversing his predecessor’s approval of a project to move oil from Canada to the Gulf of Mexico, according to a person familiar with Mr. Biden’s plans for his first days in office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Biden’s 10-day blitz of executive orders.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2 Million Homes in California
description: A modern townhouse in Laguna Beach, a two-bedroom condominium in San Francisco and a 1932 stone cottage in Burbank.
content: This townhouse is in a new four-unit complex called The Sheds, designed by Horst Architects. Set between the campuses of Laguna College of Art and Design (about five minutes from each campus on foot), the units are meant to evoke the live-work style of artists’ lofts, with multiple balconies and open floor plans that allow for flexible use. The property is tucked into the base of Laguna Canyon, close to hiking trails, and is a five-minute drive from the Pacific Ocean and the Laguna beaches, as well as the upscale dining and shopping of downtown Laguna Beach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Underselling the Vaccine
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: Early in the pandemic, many health experts — in the U.S. and around the world — decided that the public could not be trusted to hear the truth about masks. Instead, the experts spread a misleading message, discouraging the use of masks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Crouse
title: ‘I Let You Down’: Klete Keller’s Path From Olympics to Capitol Riot
description: Jan. 6 wasn’t Keller’s first election protest in Washington. But as he makes tearful apologies and faces federal charges, even his closest confidants aren’t sure why he was there at all.
content: The swimming coach did not know what to expect when he dialed Klete Keller’s phone number.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: In Minnesota, a G.O.P. Lawmaker’s Death Brings Home the Reality of Covid
description: Minnesota Republicans celebrated election victories with a gala party. A state senator’s death from Covid-19 underlined the consequences of the G.O.P.’s rejection of health experts’ guidance.
content: Republicans in the Minnesota State Senate were feeling jubilant after the November election. They had held onto a slim majority following an onslaught by Democrats trying to win control. Now, it was time to party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: This M.L.K. Day, America Has a ‘Long Road Ahead’
description: White supremacy was built on lies. In a reality-denying age, it follows that racism has flourished.
content: On Jan. 5, exactly 10 days before what would have been the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s 92nd birthday, the Rev. Raphael Warnock, the senior pastor of King’s former church, won election to become Georgia’s first Black senator.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: What Would You Do First if You Were the New President?
description: On Wednesday, Joseph R. Biden Jr. will be sworn in as the 46th president of the United States. What do you think should be the goals and priorities for the new Biden-Harris administration?
content: On Wednesday, Joseph R. Biden Jr. will be sworn in as the 46th president of the United States. Mr. Biden, along with Vice President-elect Kamala Harris, will set forth a new vision and direction for this country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mariel Wamsley
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Salt-N-Pepa’ and ‘Painting With John’
description: Lifetime airs a movie about the all-female rap group. And John Lurie shares his wisdom on HBO.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Jan. 18-24. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil
title: Tennessee Fires Football Coach Amid Investigation
description: Coach Jeremy Pruitt and nine members of his football program’s staff were fired after ongoing investigations into the team’s recruitment practices showed violations of N.C.A.A. rules.
content: The University of Tennessee fired Jeremy Pruitt, its head football coach, and nine other staff members after the school investigated whether the program violated N.C.A.A. recruitment regulations, the school announced Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Europe Welcomes Biden, but Won’t Wait for Him
description: The European Union is eager for “a political climate change” and cooperation, but if the new president is consumed with domestic problems, it won’t put its own agenda on hold.
content: BRUSSELS — Europe is eager for “a political climate change” after Joseph R. Biden Jr. is sworn in on Wednesday, but if the new American president is preoccupied with troubles at home it is prepared to move ahead in key areas on its own, European leaders and analysts say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Regnery Publishing picks up Senator Hawley’s book after it was dropped by Simon & Schuster.
description: The conservative publishing house said Senator Josh Hawley had been the victim of cancel culture.
content: Regnery Publishing, a conservative publishing house, said Monday that it had picked up a book by Senator Josh Hawley, Republican of Missouri, after Simon & Schuster ended its contract to publish it in the wake of the assault on the Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Dominion Voting Systems threatens to sue Mike Lindell, MyPillow C.E.O., over false claims.
description: Officials with Dominion Voting Systems have sent Mike Lindell, the C.E.O. of MyPillow, a legal letter warning of pending litigation over his baseless claims of widespread fraud involving their machines.
content: Officials with Dominion Voting Systems have sent Mike Lindell, the C.E.O. of MyPillow, a legal letter warning of pending litigation over his baseless claims of widespread fraud involving their machines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Some problems in India’s vaccine rollout.
content: India’s coronavirus vaccine rollout, one of the largest in the world, has been hobbled by technical glitches in a mobile phone application, leaving the country far short of its vaccination goals in the first few days of the campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: Most Major Economies Are Shrinking. Not China’s.
description: The Chinese economy grew 2.3 percent last year, the country’s National Bureau of Statistics announced on Monday in Beijing.
content: SHANGHAI — As most nations around the world struggle with new lockdowns and layoffs in the face of the surging pandemic, just one major economy has bounced back after bringing the coronavirus mostly under control: China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Rash of Coronavirus Cases Poses Early Challenge for the Australian Open
description: With several positive tests among people arriving from abroad, and a strict quarantine, the Australian Open is not going the way organizers expected it would.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — It was late December, and Craig Tiley was feeling good. After months of negotiations with government officials and the world’s top tennis players, Tiley, the head of Tennis Australia, finally had the green light to stage the Australian Open in the middle of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Peter Baker
title: Biden plans to roll out dozens of executive orders in his first 10 days as president.
description: President-elect Joe Biden’s team has developed a raft of decrees that he can issue after the inauguration to begin reversing some of President Trump’s policies.
content: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. plans to start his administration with dozens of executive directives on top of expansive legislative proposals in a 10-day blitz meant to signal a turning point for a nation reeling from disease, economic turmoil, racial strife and now the aftermath of the assault on the Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Trump’s ‘1776 report’ defends America’s founding on the basis of slavery and blasts progressivism.
description: The Trump White House released the report of the presidential “1776 Commission,” a sweeping attack on liberal thought and activism that calls for a “patriotic education,” defends America’s founding on the basis of slavery and likens progressivism to fascism.
content: The Trump White House on Monday released the report of the presidential “1776 Commission,” a sweeping attack on liberal thought and activism that calls for a “patriotic education,” defends America’s founding on the basis of slavery and likens progressivism to fascism.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Jan. 18, 2021
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Jan. 18, 2021.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Jan. 18, 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: How Full Employment Became Washington’s Creed
description: Policymakers are eager to return to the period of low unemployment that preceded the pandemic and are less concerned than in previous eras about sparking inflation and taking on debt.
content: As President-elect Joseph R. Biden, Jr. prepares to take office this week, his administration and the Federal Reserve are pointed toward a singular economic goal: Get the job market back to where it was before the pandemic hit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Velsey
title: Making a Home of Her Own in Brooklyn
description: After several years of hunting, a domestic violence survivor and her daughter finally find a home, in East New York.
content: It took Kaleena Small more than three years to find an apartment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: For the most part, far-right groups stayed away from protests on Sunday as statehouses turned into citadels.
description: The last weekend of the Trump presidency wound down with state capitols across the nation ringed by barricades, military vehicles guarding closed-off streets and Washington, D.C., all but shut down. In the end, it was for a handful of protesters, most from the right, a few from the left, many looking more like ragtag stragglers than the furious mob of Trump supporters that ransacked the U.S. Capitol more than a week ago.
content: The last weekend of the Trump presidency wound down with state capitols across the nation ringed by barricades, military vehicles guarding closed-off streets and Washington, D.C., all but shut down. In the end, it was for a handful of protesters, most from the right, a few from the left, many looking more like ragtag stragglers than the furious mob of Trump supporters that ransacked the U.S. Capitol more than a week ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh
title: California recommends pausing a batch of Moderna vaccines after possible ‘severe’ allergic reactions.
description: The state epidemiologist made the recommendation after several people who received the vaccine at one community clinic needed medical attention in the span of 24 hours.
content: The California state epidemiologist has recommended that the state pause the distribution of more than 330,000 doses of the Moderna vaccine after a “higher than usual” number of people showed signs of a possible severe allergic reaction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Harmon, Audra D. S. Burch, Thomas Fuller and Manny Fernandez
title: One Day’s Pandemic Losses: Among Thousands, a Father, a Child, a Friend
description: The lives of the people who died on a single January day reflect an extraordinary national loss.
content: It was 3 a.m. when Latraile Williams was startled from her sleep in her family’s Gainesville, Fla., home with a phone call. The voice on the other end, the doctor, sounded urgent, his words coming in slow bursts. Her husband of 23 years had very little time left. “Dear God,” she began to pray. “Dear God, give me strength.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Phil Spector: Listening to 15 Songs From a Violent Legacy
description: He was convicted of murder and died an inmate in California, but the producer’s work in the early 1960s is an inextricable part of pop music history.
content: Phil Spector died Saturday as an inmate in California, convicted of the 2003 murder of Lana Clarkson. By then, other facts had emerged about his volatile, erratic, gun-toting behavior, notably in Ronnie Spector’s 1990 memoir, “Be My Baby,” which detailed his abuses during their seven-year marriage. Some listeners may well decide that all of his music is poisoned. But it is also inextricable from pop history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Kenneth P. Vogel and Dana Rubinstein
title: Trump Prepares Pardon Wave for Final Hours
description: Among those under consideration for grants of clemency are the former New York Assembly speaker Sheldon Silver and the rapper Lil Wayne.
content: Those under consideration include such disparate figures as Sheldon Silver, the disgraced former New York Assembly speaker, and the rapper Lil Wayne, who pleaded guilty last month to a gun charge. Rudolph W. Giuliani says he does not expect one, and Stephen K. Bannon’s chances seem to have dimmed. Mixed in among the big names, low-level drug offenders are under consideration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Fox Settled a Lawsuit Over Its Lies. But It Insisted on One Unusual Condition.
description: Why did the network insist an agreement with the family of a murdered young man remain undisclosed until after the election?
content: On Oct. 12, 2020, Fox News agreed to pay millions of dollars to the family of a murdered Democratic National Committee staff member, implicitly acknowledging what saner minds knew long ago: that the network had repeatedly hyped a false claim that the young staff member, Seth Rich, was involved in leaking D.N.C. emails during the 2016 presidential campaign. (Russian intelligence officers, in fact, had hacked and leaked the emails.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein, Lauren Hirsch and Andrew Ross Sorkin
title: Gary Gensler Is Picked to Lead S.E.C.
description: The Biden administration also named Rohit Chopra as the head of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, in moves that would bring Obama-era regulators to oversee key financial agencies.
content: The Biden administration said on Monday that it is tapping two financial regulators from the Obama administration to oversee key departments that had loosened their grip of the industry under President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Vaccine Critics Received More Than $1 Million in Pandemic Relief Loans
description: The Paycheck Protection Program’s loose rules allowed organizations that have questioned the safety of vaccines to qualify for aid.
content: The Paycheck Protection Program’s loose rules allowed virtually any small business or company in America to qualify for a government-backed relief loan. Frustrated citizens and activist groups have criticized thousands of recipients they deemed unworthy, including wealthy lawyers, politicians and political lobbyists, publicly traded companies and businesses under government investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Trump Isn’t Out the Door Yet
description: But after a few terrible weeks, there are reasons for Americans to be cautiously optimistic.
content: Bret Stephens: Gail, given what’s happened in the past two weeks, Martin Luther King Jr. Day feels particularly meaningful this year. It seems as if the country is just holding its breath, waiting for the next Capitol Hill mob to descend, somewhere, somehow, on something or someone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Wu
title: Twins with Covid-19 help scientists untangle the disease’s genetic roots.
description: Kimberly and Kelly Standard, who are twins, assumed that when they became sick with Covid-19 their experiences would be as identical as their DNA.
content: Kimberly and Kelly Standard, who are twins, assumed that when they became sick with Covid-19 their experiences would be as identical as their DNA.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: The Mystery of the Painting Thieves Love
description: What is it about a Frans Hals painting housed at a tiny Dutch museum that has made it so popular with thieves, who have stolen it three times since 1988?
content: “Two Laughing Boys with a Mug of Beer,” a painting by Frans Hals, has hung in a tiny museum in Leerdam, a town in the Netherlands, for most of the past 248 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The Extraordinary Courage of Aleksei Navalny
description: After a near-fatal poisoning, Russia’s top dissident steps back into the bear’s den.
content: Aleksei Navalny knew he would be arrested as soon as he stepped foot on Russian soil, and he had no illusions about what this could mean.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: The Devilish Life and Art of Lucian Freud, in Full Detail
description: William Feaver’s “The Lives of Lucian Freud: Fame, 1968-2011” completes a two-volume biography of the pioneering realist painter.
content: The critic Kenneth Tynan divided playwrights into two categories, “smooth” and “hairy,” and one could probably make a similar distinction among biographers. Smooth biographers offer clean narrative lines, well-underscored themes, and carrots, in the form of cliffhangers, to lure the reader onward. Their books are on best-seller lists. They’re good gifts for Dad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner, Alan Feuer and Adam Goldman
title: Justice Dept. charges militia members, including military veterans, in Capitol assault.
description: The acting U.S. attorney in Washington said that focusing on militia members and other extremists would be a top priority.
content: The Justice Department has charged suspected members of the Three Percenters, a militia group that emerged some years ago from the extremist wing of the gun-rights movement, and of the Oath Keepers, a far-right militia group founded by law enforcement and military veterans, as it works to determine whether the extremist groups conspired to attack Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: Paging Through Broadway While the Stages Are Dark
description: As she packs her things to make a move, a critic lingers over her memories, many slickly packaged, some not.
content: I admit it: I’m supposed to be packing. I’m starting 2021 with a move, to my first solo apartment, and I was doing pretty well for a while: rolled up the rug, took down some artwork, packed four bins of books without pausing (Flo Rida’s “My House” played on Spotify as an aspirational track). It was the Playbills that got me, the unwieldy stack at the top of the bookcase that leaned sloppily, as though at any moment a handful would slide off and escape to the floor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Adams
title: Finding a Foothold for Nordic Skiing in Rural Alaska
description: The harsh wind-hammered tundra sometimes complicates the prospect, as do the polar bears. But the children are enthusiastic pupils.
content: It was minus 40 degrees Fahrenheit, and a lot of the children were wearing jeans. They forgot to bring snow pants again. But they wanted to go skiing anyway, and that’s why we were there, so we took them skiing — even if a few of the less appropriately dressed kids turned back early.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon and Judith Levitt
title: Your Evening Briefing: Inauguration and Executive Orders
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Anti-vaccine groups received more than $1 million in small-business relief loans.
description: Six organizations that have challenged the safety of vaccines and made claims that scientists have called false received loans.
content: The Paycheck Protection Program’s loose rules allowed virtually any small business or company in America to qualify for a government-backed relief loan. Citizens and activist groups have criticized thousands of recipients that they deemed unworthy, including wealthy lawyers, politicians and political lobbyists, publicly traded companies and businesses under government investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Questions Hover Over Samsung as Chief Returns to Prison for Bribery
description: South Korea’s family-run conglomerates helped rebuild the country after the Korean War, but they are now seen by many as corrupting influences on the political system.
content: SEOUL, South Korea — ​Lee Jae-yong, chief of the sprawling Samsung conglomerate, returned to prison on Monday for bribing a former South Korean president, leaving major questions hanging over the fate of one of the world’s largest business empires.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer and Christopher Flavelle
title: Businesses Aim to Pull Greenhouse Gases From the Air. It’s a Gamble.
description: A surge of corporate money could soon transform carbon removal from science fiction to reality. But there are risks: The very idea could offer industry an excuse to maintain dangerous habits.
content: Using technology to suck carbon dioxide out of the sky has long been dismissed as an impractical way to fight climate change — physically possible, but far too expensive to be of much use.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Carey
title: The Potential Plus of Having a Former ‘English Learner’ as Education Secretary
description: Like a growing number of U.S. students today, Miguel Cardona learned English in school, not at home.
content: When Miguel Cardona was 5, he started kindergarten in public school. His parents had moved from Puerto Rico to Meriden, Conn., where he was born. His father worked as a city police officer, and his family lived in public housing. They spoke Spanish at home. When Miguel began school, English was something of a mystery. He was, in the term educators use today, an English learner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu and Marc Tracy
title: Investors Push Home Depot and Omnicom to Steer Ads From Misinformation
description: Companies have struggled to keep their ad dollars from going to online outlets that promoted fraudulent theories about the 2020 election.
content: Shareholders in Home Depot and the advertising giant Omnicom have filed resolutions asking the companies to investigate whether the money they spent on advertisements may have helped spread hate speech and misinformation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Jeffery C. Mays
title: Rivals Mock Andrew Yang: 5 Takeaways From the Mayor’s Race
description: Andrew Yang’s visit to a “bodega” drew digs from other contenders, and his entry in the New York City’s race seemed to shake up the contest.
content: Andrew Yang made a big splash last week as he entered the mayor’s race, adding a jolt of energy to a campaign season that has been relatively staid and polite until now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Russian Court Orders Aleksei Navalny Held for 30 Days
description: Mr. Navalny, the Russian opposition leader, was arrested at a Moscow airport after five months in Germany, recovering from a near-fatal poisoning.
content: MOSCOW — A judge ordered the Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny to be jailed for 30 days, ahead of a decision that could put him behind bars for years, after an extraordinary, rushed court hearing on Monday held inside a police station within a day of his return from Germany.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: Census Bureau director resigns from post one year before term ends after claims that he politicized his role.
description: Steven Dillingham resigned on Monday as director of the Census Bureau, bringing an early end to a tumultuous tenure that culminated this month in charges that he had allowed politics to override policy at the nation’s premier statistical agency.
content: Steven Dillingham resigned on Monday as director of the Census Bureau, bringing an early end to a tumultuous tenure that culminated this month in charges that he had allowed politics to override policy at the nation’s premier statistical agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: Red curry lentils, a shrimp scampi with orzo or a satisfying chicken French.
content: It’s a federal holiday, a day of service, commemorating the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in 1929. He would have been 92. Before you think of food today, spend a little time reading his sermons and speeches, and our accounting in The New York Times of his assassination in 1968. He was 39.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: For One British Industry, Brexit’s Red Tape Is Just Beginning
description: Chemical companies, facing costly new regulations and extra tariffs, are looking to the continent.
content: For nearly a century the firm of Teal & Mackrill in the port city of Hull in northeast England has made paints for special applications, like fishing trawlers and factory floors. It produces marine paint, for example, with ingredients to prevent barnacles from encrusting hulls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: Will Biden’s Stimulus Package Help Reverse the ‘Shecession’?
description: Experts say the $1.9 trillion package will help women get back to work. Here’s how.
content: — C. Nicole Mason, president and chief executive of the Institute for Women’s Policy Research
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Veena Dubal and Juliet B. Schor
title: Gig Workers Are Employees. Start Treating Them That Way.
description: The Biden administration has an opportunity to restore basic labor protections to the people who deliver our groceries and drive for Uber and Lyft.
content: One of the nation’s largest grocery chains, Albertsons, announced this month that it would replace many of its staff delivery drivers with independent contractors working for the delivery service DoorDash. Those contractors will not receive important labor protections that have been provided to the full-time employees they will be replacing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Coral Davenport
title: Biden to Cancel Keystone XL Pipeline in Inauguration Day Executive Order
description: The project had already been languishing, but the action by Mr. Biden would signal his determination to undo President Trump’s environmental legacy.
content: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. is expected to cancel the Keystone XL pipeline permit on his first day in office, quickly reversing his predecessor’s approval of a project to move oil from Canada to the Gulf of Mexico long opposed by environmentalists, according to a person familiar with Mr. Biden’s plans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rich Benjamin
title: The Youthful Movement That Made Martin Luther King Jr.
description: In this moment made so dark by white nationalism and truth denial, Americans should look to the country’s legacy of young leaders with forward-thinking wisdom.
content: There’s an image of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. that’s seared into my mind. Eyes inviting and innocent, face relaxed, the casually dressed Dr. King reminds me of a cousin at a card party — he looks so young. When Dr. King elucidated his dream at the March on Washington in 1963, he was 34 — younger than most Americans now, given the national median age of 38.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: In Minnesota, a G.O.P. lawmaker’s death brings home the reality of the pandemic.
description: Republicans in the Minnesota State Senate were feeling jubilant after the November election. They had held onto a slim majority despite an onslaught by Democrats. Now, it was time to party.
content: Republicans in the Minnesota State Senate were feeling jubilant after the November election. They had held onto a slim majority despite an onslaught by Democrats. Now, it was time to party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martin Luther King III
title: My Father, Martin Luther King Jr., Had Another Dream
description: If he saw the issues of poverty and income inequality that exist today, he would be greatly disappointed.
content: As we celebrate the legacy of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. today — with just a few days until a new administration takes office — we must think about the message he would have for our country and our leadership at this moment. In the video op-ed above, his son Martin Luther King III challenges us to confront what Dr. King was fighting for when he was killed in Memphis in 1968. His cause and his message about poverty and workers’ rights resonated then but unfortunately resonate now more than ever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: Pompeo, Who Led Trump’s Mission at State Dept., Leaves With a Dubious Legacy
description: As Secretary of State Mike Pompeo looks to his political future, his turbulent tenure is characterized by investigations into his leadership and ethics.
content: WASHINGTON — Spurned by many foreign allies, ridiculed by adversaries, disliked by a significant number of his own diplomats and trying to preserve his political future, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo last week offered an insight into his legacy as a commander of the Trump administration’s scorched-earth foreign policy by citing a seminal moment in his personal history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: Some Republicans have turned to conspiracy theories and misinformation to explain the Capitol attack.
description: Immediately after the attack on the U.S. Capitol, all corners of the political spectrum repudiated the mob of President Trump’s supporters. Yet within days, prominent Republicans, party officials, conservative media voices and rank-and-file voters began making a rhetorical shift to try to downplay the group’s violent actions.
content: Immediately after the attack on the U.S. Capitol, all corners of the political spectrum repudiated the mob of President Trump’s supporters. Yet within days, prominent Republicans, party officials, conservative media voices and rank-and-file voters began making a rhetorical shift to try to downplay the group’s violent actions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dionne Searcey and Matthew Rosenberg
title: An Inaugural Lockdown Comes at a Price for Washingtonians
description: The nation’s capital has been secured with checkpoints, tens of thousands of National Guard troops and miles of fencing and barricades, security at the cost of normalcy.
content: WASHINGTON — Chuck Weathers was waiting Monday morning on a bus in Columbia Heights, a residential neighborhood of shops and quaint homes about four miles north of the Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Corum and Carl Zimmer
title: Inside the B.1.1.7 Coronavirus Variant
description: What researchers have learned about the U.K. variant.
content: What researchers have learned about the U.K. variant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Presidential Children’s Books, Pets and All
description: When Joe Biden takes office, there will be several children's book authors and subjects in the White House.
content: When Joe Biden takes office, there will be several children's book authors and subjects in the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $1.2 Million in California
description: A modern townhouse in Laguna Beach, a two-bedroom condominium in San Francisco and a 1932 stone cottage in Burbank.
content: A modern townhouse in Laguna Beach, a two-bedroom condominium in San Francisco and a 1932 stone cottage in Burbank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martin Luther King III, Asaf Kastner and Adam Saewitz
title: My Father, Martin Luther King Jr., Had Another Dream
description: If he saw the issues of poverty and income inequality that exist today he would be greatly disappointed.
content: If he saw the issues of poverty and income inequality that exist today he would be greatly disappointed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Brazil Begins Administering Covid-19 Vaccine
description: Health officials in Brazil recently began giving the first Covid-19 vaccinations after the country’s health regulator approved two vaccines for emergency use.
content: Health officials in Brazil recently began giving the first Covid-19 vaccinations after the country’s health regulator approved two vaccines for emergency use.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yousur Al-Hlou and Kassie Bracken
title: Small Group of Armed Protesters Gather at Michigan Capitol
description: In Michigan, government officials and law enforcement prepared for the possibility of significant violence ahead of the inauguration, but by Sunday’s end only a small group of armed protesters had ventured to the state capitol.
content: In Michigan, government officials and law enforcement prepared for the possibility of significant violence ahead of the inauguration, but by Sunday’s end only a small group of armed protesters had ventured to the state capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brent McDonald, Emily Rhyne and Ben Laffin
title: Gun Rights Rally in Richmond Draws Small Crowd
description: Virginia’s State Capitol building was surrounded by police officers and news reporters, who outnumbered the small knots of heavily armed gun-rights supporters.
content: Virginia’s State Capitol building was surrounded by police officers and news reporters, who outnumbered the small knots of heavily armed gun-rights supporters.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Senator Hawley’s Canceled Book Deal: No First Amendment Issue
description: A reader says publishers aren’t bound by free-speech protections. Also: Remote work; evictions in the pandemic; landlords in a bind.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
